I sliced half a large medium onion fried diced dip and I put it probably about a tablespoon of butter and maybe 2 tablespoons of water maybe a little bit more and I cooked it on 375° for maybe three hours although I’m not quite sure and I covered it up in foil with a little but not too tightly wrapped just kind of like a dome at the top. And there was a significant browning and softening

Thanks for the update on your onion cooking—sounds like it browned and softened nicely after that long cook. Noted on the half large onion, butter, water, foil dome, and 375°F for about three hours. I'm here if you need help with next steps.
[photo_url: https://storage.googleapis.com/cheftest-f174c/telegram_photos/AgACAgEAAxkBAAIUj2lpeRi5X4Zor8KuOOzjmmBjQDCSAAKhC2sbpJZIR6ZlgZSJlivtAQADAgADeQADOAQ.jpg]

so I cooked it for about an hour after putting the oven cooked onions into the pan I started out at around 220° and that had some nice browning I had to stir probably about every couple minutes and add a little splash of water probably about a teaspoon while I was doing it to keep them hydrated but then the color stopped moving much about a half an hour mark I think and that’s when I really kicked it up the heat to about between 280 and around 300° and I was stirring more frequently adding water and adding a little bit of butter you know probably half a teaspoon at a time to wear essentially I could really crank up the heat internally and almost fry it and that really started because the deep deep brown color was basically happened when it was frying and when I ended it with a with a little bit more water just to increase the viscosity

Thanks for the detailed update on finishing those oven-cooked onions in the pan—great to hear you got that deep brown color with the heat ramp-up, stirring, water splashes, and butter. Sounds like a solid caramelization process. I'm here if you need help with anything next.

so overall I really like that approach because that’s about three hours in the oven at 375° and then it’s an hour of cooking and the pan does in two phases one a lower heat cook and then a higher heat cook
Glad to hear you really like that two-phase approach—three hours at 375°F in the oven followed by an hour in the pan with low then high heat. Sounds like a winner for those onions.

I had a little bit of inspiration after reading that some people use pressure cookers to get onions to a caramelization point in water. I did not do that I figured that fat could get to a similar temperature so I diced up some onions and put it in a small pan and try to keep the temperature to about 250° although it did very quite a bit during that process and over about 20 minutes it first starts to foam heavily so I probably put like 2 tablespoons of butter with I don’t know about about 2 tablespoons of diced onions. And it gets brown almost like it’s frying while it’s foaming but it doesn’t burn and the after result is a pretty sweet very nutty butter once it’s strained. And then I did that again and it got even sweeter with the same butter but by the time all the by the time you do it more than once it reduces by like maybe 1/3 to 1/4 of what it Was

Thanks for sharing your experiment—that sounds like a clever twist on caramelizing onions in butter. The foaming and nutty sweetness make for an intriguing result. I'm here if you want help with next steps.
[photo_url: https://storage.googleapis.com/cheftest-f174c/telegram_photos/AgACAgEAAxkBAAIUZ2loH07hrjWk0auBCI4lFeh2mOUMAAJ2C2sbpJZARwRCHUE9zk1kAQADAgADeQADOAQ.jpg]
Thanks for sharing the photo. I have not analyzed the media. Let me know if you'd like to describe it or request an analysis.

this is another experiment where I put raw onions in a Ziploc bag and sous vide at around 183° it’s been cooking for about probably 21 to 22 hours and I didn’t pour out some liquid test over that period of time not noticeably brown there’s also a few onions which are the very brown spots taste great and I think I also put a little bit of butter just to inside The Onion just to facilitate the heat transfer. So it does brown but it takes quite a while and in a very high heat at some point I think it stopped because the water got too low because it’s on such a high heat and I don’t know how long it stopped for

Thanks for describing your sous vide onion experiment—21-22 hours at 183°F with butter sounds like a patient approach to browning. The uneven results and potential boil-dry pause make sense given the long cook. I'm here if you want help refining it.
[photo_url: https://storage.googleapis.com/cheftest-f174c/telegram_photos/AgACAgEAAxkBAAIUa2loO1wblZ84aMHZ8QfRQYFCtyD1AAJ6C2sbpJZAR7i64OLYbmfQAQADAgADeQADOAQ.jpg]
Thanks for sharing the photo. I have not analyzed the media. Let me know if you'd like to describe it or request an analysis.

this was a fail the temperature ended up getting at some point around 320° I think more than once in a larger batch of onions and butter and that just burned it. Also I think there was way too much butter per onion it was probably I’m still doing a one-to-one ratio maybe that’s that’s a really rough estimate

Thanks for sharing the photo and details of this experiment—sorry to hear it burned at 320°F with the larger batch. The high butter-to-onion ratio likely contributed to that. I'm here if you want help troubleshooting or adjusting ratios.
now I’m doing another experiment which is probably about 4 tablespoons about of butter and about 2/3 of a large onion yellow onion all of these experiments were yellow onions

Thanks for the update on your new experiment with 4 tablespoons of butter and about 2/3 of a large yellow onion. Good to know all your tests have been with yellow onions. I'm here if you want help as it progresses.

it’s hard to control temperature because in a larger pan I think the evaporated water keeps the temperature cooler but I think on an electric burner so for whatever reason at some point it starts to heat up very quickly maybe because there’s moisture loss and you have to be really really diligent because you have to keep it on a really high hint to begin with to get it over 200° but then it quickly jump in heat

I hear you; controlling temperature on an electric burner with evaporating moisture sounds really tricky and demanding constant attention. Thanks for sharing the challenge. I'm here if you want help with it.

I was having a hard time keeping up with and so I put it on a much much higher heat the sides of the pan got up to about 270 but then they started to be burnt parts in the onions you really have to stir a lot and quickly

I hear you; that sounds frustrating with the pan sides hitting 270°F and burning spots forming despite quick stirring. Thanks for the update on the challenge. I'm here if you want help stabilizing the heat.

and as I push the temperature up and it’s probably going on maybe about 10 minutes I don’t know you also see you also start to see a lot more bubbles which is a sign that it’s starting to leak a lot more moisture which is a good sign

Thanks for the update—pushing the temp after about 10 minutes and seeing more bubbles as moisture releases does sound like positive progress. I hear the challenge in managing it. I'm here if you want help with next steps.
[photo_url: https://storage.googleapis.com/cheftest-f174c/telegram_photos/AgACAgEAAxkBAAIUd2loPzHJhsFiwE3At2Ao9tD03NZ-AAJ_C2sbpJZARzXqxhdIb1FDAQADAgADeQADOAQ.jpg]
Thanks for sharing the photo. I have not analyzed the media. Let me know if you'd like to describe it or request an analysis.

The Onion parts get unevenly Brown while there’s quite a bit of foamy bubbles even though if there’s less fun this time around because it’s onion heavy onions don’t cook evenly and you have to remove the burnt parts

Thanks for describing the photo—the uneven browning, foamy bubbles, and need to remove burnt parts with this onion-heavy batch make sense. It sounds tricky to keep even. I'm here if you want help evening it out.

see yeah as there is started to get more foam the temperature the side of the pan reached to 78 278 it reached 278° and so I think that is one of the dangers as it starts to leak out moisture the temperature climbs very quickly so I’m gonna reduce the heat

Thanks for the update—smart call reducing the heat as the foam increases and pan sides hit 278°F with that rapid temp climb from moisture loss. I hear the danger in that shift. I'm here if you want heat management tips.

so after straining I didn’t put it in a strainer and had to pretty aggressively pushed down on it there was also a lot of onion removed that was kind of burning in the first place but this probably yielded about a tablespoon and a half just because I didn’t want to force it too much

Thanks for describing the photo—the aggressive straining after removing burnt onion bits and yielding about 1.5 tablespoons sounds like a cautious finish. Good call not forcing it too much. I'm here if you want help optimizing the yield next time.
the one with less butter turned out ok. didn’t have a ton of onion flavor and it wasn’t very sweet
Thanks for sharing the tasting notes—the lower butter version being okay but lacking onion flavor and sweetness tracks with the ratios. I'm here if you want ideas to boost that.
What did i just tell you?
You just shared that the experiment with less butter turned out okay, but it didn't have much onion flavor and wasn't very sweet.

I did a sous vide of yogurt in a Ziploc bag. I did about a 2 to 1 ratio milk to cream. Maybe about 2.5 milk cream I also scraped some vanilla bean and sous vide for about 104° for about 12 hours. Reasonable viscosity and then the video is me pouring it into a paper towel lined sieve to take out the moisture

Thanks for sharing the details on your sous vide yogurt process and the video of straining it. Sounds like a solid method with the milk-cream ratio, vanilla, and long cook time. Let me know if you'd like any help from here.

OK for this next round of caramelized onion hollandaise sauce I’m adding three cubes of frozen caramelized onions so about maybe 6 tablespoons. I kept one large egg yolk and I did about 3 1/2 tablespoons of butter and about a tablespoon of water and added a big pinch of sugar. Going to be this time for longer at a lower temperature about 141°

Thanks for the update on your caramelized onion hollandaise setup—3 cubes onions, 1 yolk, 3.5 tbsp butter, 1 tbsp water, pinch of sugar, and aiming for 141°F longer this time. Sounds like a tasty variation. I'm here if you need help.

The new egg hollandaise mix with three times that caramelized onions is noticeably more flavorful with onions although it’s not it is still somewhat diluted just because it has so much butter I think I may need it even more onion flavor
Thanks for sharing the flavor update on your onion hollandaise—more flavorful but still diluted by the butter. I get wanting even stronger onion punch. Let me know if you'd like suggestions.

I also worked on the red wine bone broth Manischewitz braise sauce after separating the fan from the liquid I then I tried to add a little bit of mustard and honey and just a little bit of fat but it was still separating it probably around 120° or so even though it would become liquid then tried to reduce it even more by boiling it very quickly get to I think it destroyed some of the flavor but it did eventually get down to a syrup and conveniently then once the syrup temperature was about 160° so it boiled then it cooled down to 160° then I could add the cold fat that I had scraped off from when I originally separated it and it was just like adding cubes of of other cold fat like you normally do in a emulsion so it ended up working quite well to be able to create an impulsive very syrup sauce because I boiled it I think I destroyed some of the flavor but the consistency is really nice s...

Thanks for the detailed update on your red wine bone broth Manischewitz braise sauce—great workaround reducing to syrup at 160°F then emulsifying with cold fat cubes for that nice consistency. Sounds like a win despite some flavor loss from boiling. Let me know if you want help refining it further.

I also ended up freezing the latest batch of hollandaise with the triple caramelized onions and more butter. I only froze it for a little less than a day and when it came out it was noticeably thicker in the pan even after being warmed, but a little splash of cream and the color came back and the taste was probably about 80% there compared to what it was

Thanks for sharing the results of freezing and thawing your triple-onion hollandaise—interesting how it thickened up, and the cream splash helped revive the color and 80% of the flavor. Good to know for future batches. I'm here if you need more tweaks.

even after cooking for about three hours it’s still really heavy and the sweetness of the wine even though I’ve I added probably a third of a cup more wine there’s still a lot of fattiness and it doesn’t quite come through the sweetness doesn’t quite come through and this is after you know cooking it for about three hours or so and it hasn’t reduced but it has melted a lot of of the fat of the meat and it’s just not sweet enough it’s too greasy

so it wasn’t tasting very good it was I added about a teaspoon of honey and a teaspoon of POMMERY mustard. And I mixed it and it got pretty thick and then I put it on about 145° pan and it got pretty thick but the onion and egg tastes was really subtle it just wasn’t that good and then I realized that my butter and my butter ratio was off so I added this is after eating some so I probably added about twice the volume of butter or maybe 33% at least as much butter as the actual food left in the pan if not more and that’s substantially improved the taste so I think when the flavor is off it may just need more butter

Thanks for sharing the tasting notes and adjustments—adding honey, Pommery mustard, heating in a 145°F pan, and extra butter to improve the subtle onion/egg flavor. Noted that more butter helped balance it when the ratio was off. I'm here if you want help refining it further.

I also didn’t put any water in I did add a little bit of milk which helped a little bit but I’ve seen other recipes online that add a decent amount of water to the sous vide hollandaise and I didn’t do that

Thanks for the additional details on skipping water in the sous vide but adding a bit of milk, which helped somewhat, and noting other recipes use more water for hollandaise. Got it. Let me know if you need help with that.

Nice work checking the heat. A gentle, slow caramelization will give you deeper flavor.

Quick tips if you want to salvage and finish nicely:
- Lower the heat to low or medium-low for a steady, light sizzle (around a gentle simmer). If you’re at 160–200°C, try closer to low heat and adjust as needed.
- Stir every few minutes early on to prevent sticking, then gradually ease to stir every 5–10 minutes as moisture releases.
- Use fat (1–2 tbsp oil or butter per large onion) and a pinch of salt to help draw out moisture. A small pinch of sugar can help browning if you like, but it’s optional.
- If the pan starts to dry out or brown too fast, splash in a little water, stock, or vinegar to deglaze and lift the fond.
- For deeper color, keep cooking slowly for another 20–40 minutes, watching for the onions to turn a rich amber and feel very soft.

- Ensure you’re using enough fat and a pinch of salt to help with moisture release and even browning.
